uh, figures in your prediction, uh, v, the so-called offset.
That's a number which is our prediction when the features are all zeros, when x is equal to 0.
Okay, so this is- this is the regression model. Now we can make a regression model fit our general framework.
All we use is the following basis functions we use, f_1 is 1, that's- we've seen that many times so far.
And then f_i of x is x_i minus 1. So literally the f's are,
you know, the first one is 1, the next one is x- is x_1. That's actually what we would call f_2 of x is x_1 and so on.
And so, in that case you get exactly this. Our model would be a linear combination of these basis functions.
That's Theta_1 plus Theta_2x plus Theta, all the way up to n plus 1, x_n. And then we would simply write that as x transpose Theta.
Remember that that's a slice. That means that the second through the nth component, they are the ones that multiply x you see directly here.
Um and then Theta_ 1 is our offset. That's the same as v. So what we can see is that we can fit,
we can represent regression in our general data fitting- in our general data fitting,
uh, framework here, okay. So regression is a special case of,
uh, linear in the parameters least squares fitting. Now it turns out we can- the opposite is true in a weird way, um, that,
suppose we have a general, uh, fitting model, that's f hat is Theta_1 f_1 of x plus up to Theta_p x_p.
Um, and it's extremely common to have the first component equal to 1. That's called an offset in the model that are constant.
Um, in fact, it's so common that may be a lot of- sometimes a lot of systems that do this stuff for you just assume it, they don't even say it.
They just say there's an offset and you actually have to call the methods with a- basically with a minus, minus, you know, offset to actually not have the first component be 1.

but not using x, um, actually using this other vector here,
which is f_2 of x up to f_p of x. And we think of those as transformed features. Um, and then- so the point is that
our general model is this- is- it can be thought of as just regression. But what we do is we think of the f's as
transform features or feature mappings or something like that. So, and that's another- that's another way to think of how
we do this kind of general fitting is we think of- thank you, in that case you call the x's the raw features, right?
And then the f's do, they trans- they transform them like for example, if you're fitting a polynomial,
they would take the fourth power or the sixth power or something like that. So that's called- that's called data transforming or feature transforming.
And then you simply do regression. So- so they're basically the same thing. They just have slightly different notation systems.
And I should say that both notation systems are kind of widely-used.

these are going to be, uh, scalars for now, okay? So I just have a time series, doesn't matter what it is.
It could be the- well we've seen a couple of time series, right? We saw world, uh,
world petroleum consumption, right? And there the index represents year, okay?
It could be hourly temperature somewhere. It could be all sorts as- it could be the price of
something or it could be anything at all. That's all. It could be a- in some kind of economic thing.
Like it could literally be the GDP of a country or a region, okay.
It's a time series. There are a lot of time series, I mean, of course. And so we're going to talk about now is something called an autoregressive model.
Auto-regressive means that you're going to make- let me say what the model is. The model is this. It says, uh, that we're going to use the notation z hat_t plus 1.
Z hat_t plus 1 is to be interpreted as the prediction- if t is the- z- if t is now,
t plus 1 is next step. So this is actually, people would say this is the one step ahead prediction,
or it's the prediction of the next value. By the way, that's- that can be enormously useful in practice.
I mean, it doesn't- doesn't take a lot of imagination to imagine how useful this would be. If, for example, you could predict what
the temperature is going to be in the next hour or something like that, right? Or what electricity demand is going to be in the next hour?
Or what the price of something is going to be, you know, in the next one minute or one second, right?
So if you can make a prediction like that, that has a lot of- of valid- practical value.
Okay, so how do you make this- this one-step ahead prediction? Well, we're going to use bulk to, you know, you choose it,
you can call it a regression or you can choose at a linear in parameters model. But it's going to be this. It's going to be Theta_1 times z_t plus Theta_2 times z_t minus 1,
all the way up to Theta_M, capital M. M is a mnemonic for memory,
uh, in the model, right? So for example, this would be- people would refer to this. I'll show you what an ar2.
Sometimes people would put up, ah, an argument in there to say what the memory is, that's where you get capital M. And that looks like this.
It says z hat_ t plus 1 is equal to Theta_1 z_t plus Theta_ 2 times z_t minus 1.
There it is. And the model coefficients are Theta_1 and Theta_2. And it's actually beautifully interpretable.
You simply say, ah, I am predicting what the next value is going to be. And someone says, what's your prediction?
And you go, well, it's simple. It's Theta_1 times the current value, plus Theta_2 times the previous value, right?
So this is daily. It's like I will predict tomorrow's value to be a number Theta_1 times today's value plus
a number Theta_2 times yesterday's value, right? And so- and you can understand why this would be called the memory,
because basically it says that your prediction has to remember the last,
